Hatchet

%c[0,170,170,170]Hatchet - a tool that has been used for thousands of years to work with wood. In ChEZ it is used by stalkers for cutting brushwood, less often for finishing large mutants. It is a formidable weapon in the hands of a skilled stalker.
 
%c[0,153,255,255] • %c[default] used for:%c[0,170,170,170] battle 
%c[0,109,117,7] • %c[default] used for:%c[0,170,170,170] chopping down any creatures 
%c[0,18,18,165] • %c[default] used as:%c[0,170,170,170] tool for camp deployment 
%c[255,238,153,26] • %c[default] used for:%c[0,170,170,170] disassembling various equipment: boots, backpacks, - as an auxiliary tool
Fire axe

%c[0,170,170,170]Fire axe - used to complete fire panels and stands. In the CEZ, it is used by stalkers to cut down tailings, less often to achieve large mutants. It is a formidable weapon in the hands of a skilled stalker.
 
%c[0,153,255,255] • %c[default] used for:%c[0,170,170,170] battle

Hunting axe

%c[0,170,170,170]Hunting axe is a tool that has been used for thousands of years to cut down wood, as a weapon and even as a ceremonial object. The axe has many different shapes, but usually consists of a colon with a handle. In the Zone, an axe can mean both life and death.
 
%c[0,153,255,255] • %c[default] used for:%c[0,170,170,170] battle

.45 ACP FMJ rounds
.45 ACP
The .45 calibre full metal jacket round has enjoyed popularity for more than a hundred years thanks to its heavy bullet and a relatively small propelling charge. As a result, the bullet in this round is relatively slow but highly accurate and provides considerable stopping power.

12.7x55 STs-130 rounds
12.7x55mm STs-130
12.7x55 mm STs-130 - Russian rifle with subsonic bullet speed, designed by TSKIB SOO for low-noise and free of charge engagement of protected targets and manpower in heavy armored vests at ranges up to 600 meters.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV

12.7x55mm STs-130 VPS rounds
12.7x55mm STs-130 VPS
Large-caliber sniper cartridge STs-130 VPS (high penetration capability) is designed to engage silent fire of enemy's live force protected by heavy SIBs (5-6 levels of protection according to GOST R50744-95) at ranges up to 200 meters or located behind various obstacles (car trim, door, glass, fence, etc.) at ranges up to 600 meters, as well as to engage light and unarmoured vehicles.

7.92x33mm Mauser rounds
7.92x33mm Mauser
The 7.92x33mm Mauser cartridge was adopted in the first half of the last century by the German Empire, and then by the Third Reich. It was one of the most popular cartridges during two world wars. However, nowadays it is primarily used for hunting and sporting events.

7.92x57mm FMJ rounds
7.92x57mm FMJ
7.92x57mm FMJ - German rifle and submachine gun unitary cartridge with bottle-shaped sleeve with no protruding edge. Used mainly for long-range shooting, this cartridge is of higher quality than standard cartridge.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
7.62x51mm NATO rounds
7.62x51 NATO
7.62x51 NATO - army version of .308 round, which was used by NATO forces as a standard round until 5.56mm ammunition was introduced during the Vietnam War in the 70s. Nowadays, these cartridges are most often used by mercenaries around the world. 7.62x51 is a typical handgun caliber, but can also be used in sniper rifles.

7,62x51mm DU rounds
7,62x51mm DU
7.62x51 depleted uranium cartridges are produced and used by private military organizations around the world. The need to develop a DU-version of this cartridge arose during large-scale secret military operations against drug cartels in some countries.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV

.45 ACP Hydra-shock rounds
.45 Hydra-shock
Non-standard type of cartridge for .45 ACP (11.43x23 mm) caliber - half shell bullet with expansive hollow point and steel core. This combination of half shell and armor-piercing bullet has both advantages and disadvantages of both types of cartridges.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]II
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]very strong
.45 DU rounds
.45 DU
Chuck with depleted uranium core in .45 ACP caliber (11.43x23 mm). Since its first use in combat conditions, depleted uranium has been widely criticized in the international community - rumors of its harmful effects and radiation poisoning have been the main reason for the banning of depleted uranium. The bullet's core is self-sharpening, allowing it to be used against armored targets. Uranium heats up as it penetrates the target and inflicts additional damage with burns, but this process certainly doesn't lead to radiation exposure. This ammunition is actively used only by the U.S., and less effective versions are sometimes used in several other countries.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]above average
.357 HP rounds
.357 HP
.357 HP is an extended bullet cartridge. The purpose of such cartridges is to slow down the penetration of the bullet, but at the same time to cause great internal tissue damage. 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]above average
.357 Incendiary rounds
.357 Incendiary
This ammunition uses phosphorous to pierce the target. Phosphorus-supplied cartridges were first used during the First World War. At present, incendiary ammunition is used only by a small number of organizations, because not every weapon is capable of firing this type of ammunition. This ammunition is of medium quality and is sold at a very reasonable price. They do not explode when hit, but provide a reliable hit to the target.

.338 Lapua Magnum rounds
.338 Lapua Magnum
.338 Lapua Magnum is a specialized bottle-type cartridge with no protruding edge, designed for long-range army sniper rifles. The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan made this battle-tested ammunition quite affordable. The .338 Lapua Magnum ammunition is a dual-purpose cartridge: anti-personnel and anti-tank, but the antitank capability is very limited.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]strong
.338 DU rounds
.338 DU
.338 DU with depleted uranium core based on .338 Lapua Magnum cartridge. The ammunition was designed for private military organizations based in Iraq, which were opposed by numerous armored targets, mainly tanks stolen from Pakistan and infantry in bulletproof vests sold by sympathizers from the Middle East. To stop the supply of modern equipment to insurgents, three major private military organizations conducted a joint operation against arms dealers and suppliers in Iraq and Tajikistan. The .338 DU cartridge was designed to combat the armored targets involved in the operation. This cartridge is extremely rare because of the trade agreement between the companies involved in its creation, but is highly valued by those working in the military private sector. 
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]V
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]strong
12x70 Buckshot
12x70 Buckshot
The usual cartridge of the 12th caliber, equipped with a shot with a diameter of 6 mm. At close range it has a huge lethal and stopping effect. Designed for firing smoothbore weapons and shotguns.

12x76 Slug
12x76 Slug
12-gauge cartridge with a shellless bullet. Usually used for hunting large animals, but it is also suitable for other purposes: its heavy bullet does not penetrate, but actually squeezes the bulletproof vests.

12x76 Dart
12x76 Dart
Cartridge of the 12th caliber with a heavy shellless bullet. Usually used for hunting large animals, but suitable for other purposes. His heavy bullet actually pushes through bulletproof vests.

5.45x39mm AP (7N22) rounds
5.45x39 AP
An army cartridge 7H22 of 5.45x39 mm caliber with an armor-piercing bullet is used in automatic rifles of many countries participating in the Warsaw Pact. Inside the bullet is an armor-piercing core made of tool steel grade U12A. Effective against body armor.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
5,45x39mm FMJ (7N10) rounds
5,45x39mm FMJ
The army 7N10 round of 5.45x39mm caliber with high penetration bullet is used in automatic rifles of many countries-participants of the Warsaw Pact. It has reduced recoil impulse and increased direct shot range by 100 m, providing better accuracy than the old 7.62x39 mm cartridge.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]AIII
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
5.56x45mm AP rounds
5.56x45mm AP
The main armor-piercing cartridge of NATO troops of 5.56x45mm caliber with increased penetration, known under the index SS190 / M855. Effective against body armor. It is widely used in firearms of armies and special services of Western countries.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
5.56x45mm SS190 rounds
5.56x45mm SS190
A service cartridge of 5.56x45mm NATO forces for aimed fire in bursts, developed on the basis of hunting cartridges. Known as SS109. It has excellent ballistic characteristics.

7.62x54mm 7N1 rounds
7.62x54mm 7N1
7.62x54mm sniper cartridge with combined lead-steel core, specially designed for SVD. Unlike a machine-gun cartridge, 7H1 provides good accuracy and excellent penetration.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]strong
7.62x54mm 7N14 rounds
7.62x54mm 7N14
A specially designed modernized sniper cartridge of 7.62x54mm with an SNB armor-piercing bullet. The bullet is equipped with a combined core of lead and hardened steel grade U12A, capable of penetrating body armor and small obstacles. Compared with a standard cartridge of the same caliber, it has a lightweight tail section, which provides greater accuracy and improved ballistic performance.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]V
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]strong
7.62x54mm AP rounds
7.62x54mm AP
Inexpensive armor-piercing machine gun cartridge of 7.62x54mm caliber. Due to its design features, it is unsuitable for shooting with sniper rifles, therefore it is used as ammunition for the PKM machine gun. This cartridge has increased power and, thanks to the steel core, has a very good piercing ability. Powerful cartridge for powerful weapons.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]strong
Belt with 7.62x54mm PP rounds
Belt with 7.62x54mm PP
Non-dispersible metal belt with cheap 7.62x54 mm armor-piercing machine-gun rounds. Due to its design features it's unsuitable for sniper rifles, so it's used as ammunition for PKM machine gun. This round has an increased power and, thanks to the steel core, has a very good penetration. Powerful cartridge for powerful weapons.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]strong
7.62x54mm R rounds
7.62x54mm R
Inexpensive cartridge rifle caliber 7.62x54mm R, adopted by the Russian Empire at the turn of the 19th century and continued to be used in the USSR even after the end of World War II. The cartridge was originally designed for 7.62mm Mosin rifles, very popular now in the Zone. Despite its low cost, it has good penetration characteristics, not inferior to modern types of ammunition. It can also be used as a cheap alternative to ammunition for the PKM machine gun.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
9x18mm FMJ rounds
9x18mm FMJ
Cartridge with a shell bullet - with a steel core and a lead shirt under a metal shell. It has a good stopping effect, but is ineffective against body armor.

9x18mm +P+ rounds
9x18mm +P+
Cartridge with bullet increased stopping action 7N16. European marking +P+ means "very high pressure in the barrel." Compared to a conventional cartridge, the bullet speed is increased by 30%. Ineffective against body armor.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]I
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]above average
9x18mm RG028 rounds
9x18mm RG028
RG028 - a cartridge used to penetrate light armor. The purpose of the creation of WG028 was to counter opponents in personal protective equipment; for this reason, the cartridge is equipped with a hardened steel core. Unfortunately, the cartridge itself does not greatly exceed the standard 9x18, but only has increased penetration.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IIIA
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]below the average
9x19mm FMJ rounds
9x19mm FMJ
Standard 9x19 mm cartridge with shell bullet. It has good ballistic characteristics and is inexpensive to manufacture. Particularly popular due to the fact that an international convention prohibits the use of expansive bullets in battle. Ineffective against body armor.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]I
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
9x19mm PBP rounds
9x19 9x19mm PBP
A half-shell bullet with an expansive notch has a high stopping effect and is not prone to ricochets. It is used mainly as a "police" ammunition and in civilian personal protective weapons. It is ineffective against body armor because of its low penetrating potential.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]I
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]strong
9x19mm AP rounds
9x19mm AP
Armor-piercing bullet with a steel core. Designed to improve the penetration ability of pistols and submachine guns. It is used mainly by anti-terrorist and special police units when they encounter opponents protected by bulletproof vests.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]III
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]below the average
5.7x28mm SS190 rounds
5.7x28mm SS190
The 5.7x28 (SS190) round was developed by the Belgian Fabrique Nationale specifically for the FN P90 submachine gun in the mid-1980s. This round was later used in "Five SeveN" pistol. The cartridge has a higher penetration power than other pistol cartridges. The bullet reaches muzzle velocity of up to 716 m/s and can penetrate body armour. The stopping power of the bullet is three times that of the 9x19mm bullet.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]below the average
5.7x28mm SS195 rounds
5.7x28mm SS195
SS195LF (1.8 g, 720 m / s) - cartridge with an expansive bullet, has a lower breakdown ability than the SS190, but with a large stopping effect and lethal force.

9x19mm SP-6 rounds
9x39 SP-6
The subsonic armor-piercing "automatic" SP-6 cartridge is equipped with a semi-shell bullet with a partially open core made of hardened steel. Requires the use of a silencer to ensure silent shooting. Distributed in some countries participating in the Warsaw Pact. Extremely effective against body armor.

9x39mm SP-5 rounds
9x39mm SP-5
The subsonic “sniper” cartridge SP-5 is equipped with a bimetallic shell. The cavity behind the steel core is filled with lead. Requires the use of a silencer to ensure silent shooting. Distributed in some countries participating in the Warsaw Pact. Effective against body armor.

Grenade M203
M203
Grenade grenade launcher M203 caliber 40 mm. The radius of the effective area of destruction by fragments is about 3.5 m. It can also be used in the integrated grenade launcher complex FN F2000.

Projectile OG-7V
OG-7V
High-explosive fragmentation projectile for a grenade launcher. With the help of the RPG-7 launcher, it allows you to hit an enemy who has hidden behind at a distance exceeding the throwing range of a hand grenade.

Grenade VOG-25
VOG-25
Fragmentation ammunition for GP-25 "Bonfire", GP-30 "Shoes", RG-6 " Dwarf" grenades, combining grenade and projectile charge in a cartridge case. The grenade is muzzle-loading, i.e. i's fed into the barrel through the barrel.

Grenade VOG-25P
VOG-25P
Shot with a "bouncing" fragmentation grenade equipped with a VGM-P fuse with a bouncing charge and a pyrotechnic delayer. Upon hitting the obstacle the round bounces and explodes in the air at a height of about 1.5 meters. Compared to the VOG-25, the bouncing ammunition is more effective against a lying and entrenched enemy.

7.62x39mm M43 rounds
7.62x39mm M43
Ammunition 7.62x39 M43, made in China, with a bullet of increased penetration ability, which is often referred to as "7.62x39 CN." The cartridge has a soft steel core that increases penetration. This Chinese ammunition (in principle, like all other M43 cartridges) is currently banned for import into the United States, as federal law classifies it as armor-piercing. This classification is based on the materials and design of the bullet, and not on its ability to penetrate armor.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]IV
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
7.62x39mm FMJ rounds
7.62x39mm FMJ
The 7.62x39mm cartridge with an all-metal shell is one of the most popular ammunition used, especially in Africa and the Middle East. Many call it the "Bullet of the Revolution" in connection with its frequent use by both terrorists and criminal organizations. Due to the huge penetration ability of this cartridge, the military of all countries had to strengthen the armor protection of their units, since the probability of encountering this munition in combat situations is very high.
 
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Penetrates armor class: %c[0,170,170,170]AIII
%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
7.62x25mm P rounds
7.62x25mm P
Soviet pistol cartridge 7.62mm, now known as 7.62mm Tokarev. The bullet has a lead core and a steel shell clad with tompak. The initial velocity of the bullet is 420 m / s, the energy is 510 J. In order to more reliably connect the bullet to the sleeve made of brass, the bullet was fixed in the sleeve with a circular crimp of the sleeve barrel followed by roll. In the warehouses of the military units of the Armed Forces of the Russian Federation there is still a very large number of these cartridges.

%c[0,93,0,116] • %c[default] Tissue damage: %c[0,170,170,170]average
7.62x25mm PS rounds
7.62x25 PS
7.62mm pistol cartridge with a steel core bullet (7.62 PS), weight 5.6 grams mm. Adopted in 1953. The cartridge has a bimetallic (GAU Index - 57-H-134C) or brass (GAU Index - 57-H-132C) sleeve. The stopping effect of the bullet was maximally close to the performance of the 9x19 mm Parabellum bullet.

7,62x25mm P-41 rounds
7,62x25mm P-41
In 1941, the Red Army adopted the cartridge with an armor-piercing incendiary bullet with a steel core, under the designation "P-41". The head part of the PT bullet was covered with black varnish with a red stripe. In 1943, a cartridge with the tracer bullet “PT” began to be produced, which gave a red luminous trail at a distance of 350 - 400 meters.

%c[0,170,170,170]This specially designed three-chamber silencer is not designed to completely silence an IED shot, as it does not use subsonic ammunition. Its main purpose is to reduce and "smear" the sound of the shot to make it difficult for the enemy to detect the shooter. The feature of this device is a very effective muzzle brake, which can reduce the recoil force by about 40%. However, such capabilities are achieved at the cost of reduced initial velocity of the bullet, significantly reducing the potential damage to the weapon.

Smoke grenade RDG-M "Smoke"
The RDG-M "Smoke" instant-action hand grenade is designed to disguise internal affairs officers and internal servicemen from aimed fire of the enemy during special operations. Provides instant setting of a smoke masking curtain. The smoke curtain is opaque in the visible wavelength range for the entire time of existence, and at the time of formation in the infrared range. The grenade is equipped with a phosphorus-based smoke composition. There is no explosive charge in the grenade, which ensures the absence of fragments that can cause injury.

AK-12
AK-12 - Kalashnikov assault rifle of the 2012 model, the development of the Kalashnikov concern. The weapon controls are significantly redesigned for the convenience of users, the fuse-translator flag has been changed and duplicated on the left side, a slide delay has been introduced, the button of which is also located on both sides. Another innovation is the use of Picatinny rails. One of the main features of the AK-12 was the increased ergonomics of the weapon compared to the AK-74M caliber 5.45x39 and the AKM caliber 7.62x39. The work carried out increased the accuracy of fire, the reliability of the functioning of the mechanisms of weapons and increase the service life. The AK-12 uses automation with a long stroke of the gas piston and a rotary shutter, the bolt group and the trigger mechanism were significantly improved in comparison with the AK-74. The weapon is equipped with a new telescopic plastic butt, folding in both directions and adjustable in length and height of the cheek. The central axis of the barrel channel AK-12 is in line with the butt, as is the case with AR-15 assault rifles, which reduces the recoil shoulder and ultimately increases the accuracy of fire.

FN Five-seveN
The FN Five-seveN is a self-loading pistol designed and manufactured by the Belgian company Fabrique Nationale of Herstal. The name is a combination, on the one hand Five-seveN is “5-7” (5.7 is the caliber of the weapon, which is .224), and on the other, the first and last letter of the name, written in capital letters, is the abbreviation of Fabrique Nationale. Five-seveN is a full-sized self-loading pistol made according to the scheme with a half-free shutter, which uses 5.7 ? 28 mm cartridges. Polymers are widely used in its design, it is becoming increasingly popular in the civilian market, and the characteristics of the pistol also made it popular in special forces and other similar fields.

PP-2000
PP-2000 is a Russian 9-mm submachine gun developed by the design team of the Tula Instrument Design Bureau under the direction of V.P. Gryazev and A.G. Shipunova. PP-2000 is positioned as a weapon for law enforcement units operating in urban conditions, as well as a personal self-defense weapon for certain categories of military personnel. In 2006, serial production of PP-2000 for the Ministry of Internal Affairs of the Russian Federation began. The case is made of high strength plastic. The barrel channel is chrome-plated, it can also be equipped with a silencer, a collimator or an optical sight, a universal aiming strip is installed on the cover of the serial receiver.

FN P90
FN P90 - Belgian submachine gun (personal self-defense weapon), developed in 1986-1987 by the company FN Herstal. It was developed primarily for tankers and drivers of military vehicles and vehicles. It has a progressive and comfortable ergonomic design. Specifically for the P90, a cartridge of the 5.7x28 mm SS190 type was developed, which has a high breakdown power and a low degree of rebound. The bullet of this cartridge develops a muzzle velocity of up to 715 m / s and is capable of breaking through a titanium / Kevlar armored vest that meets NATO CRISAT requirements up to 20 meters.

PP-19 "Bizon"
In 1993, Kalashnikov and Dragunov (the younger ones) made the first version of a new submachine gun called the PP-19 Bizon. It was developed under the "Makarov" cartridge 9x18 (both standard and high-pulse, modernized). Its distinguishing feature is the presence of a screw (from the German "screw" - "snail") underbarrel magazine with a capacity of 64 rounds. The PP-19 automation is based on the recoil of the free shutter, the trigger mechanism is trigger, along with the fuse borrowed from the AK-74. Fire is conducted from a closed shutter, which increases the accuracy of single shots. On the original PP-19 model, sighting devices are installed that are identical to those on the AKS74U assault rifle.

Galil AR (worn)
Galil is an Israeli assault rifle developed by designer Israel Galili on the basis of the Finnish assault rifle Valmet Rk 62, which, in turn, is a variant of the Kalashnikov assault rifle. From the point of view of the internal structure, Galil is similar to a Kalashnikov assault rifle except for the use of another cartridge. Automation works by removing part of the powder gases from the bore through a gas outlet drilled at an angle of 30 degrees back directly into the gas chamber. The gas piston is chrome plated. The shutter handle, unlike the Kalashnikov assault rifle, is bent up so that it can be used with both hands. On the left above the pistol grip there is an additional flag of the fuse-translator of the firing modes. The production of Galil automatic rifles for the Israeli army was discontinued in 2006, and in 2007 the Galil were finally removed from service with the IDF (some remained in service with the guard of honor and some non-military units).

SR-25
The SR-25 is a self-loading sniper rifle developed by Eugene Stoner in the 1990s based on the design of the AR-15 rifle. Over 60% of the details in the design of the rifle are interchangeable with the AR-15. SR-25 has gas exhaust automation. The receiver is made of aluminum alloy - of two parts that are interconnected by transverse pins. The trigger mechanism makes it possible to fire single shots. The SR-25 rifle turned out to be quite successful, it provided high accuracy and therefore became popular both among civilian shooters in the USA and among police snipers. In the nineties, a variant of this rifle complete with an optical sight and a quick-detachable silencer of the same company was adopted by the US Navy Special Operations Forces under the designation Mark 11 Model 0 (Mk.11 Mod.0) sniper rifle.

M60
M60 - an American unified machine gun, developed in the postwar years and adopted by the Army and Marine Corps in 1957. For design flaws and appearance received the nickname English. the pig - "pig." Despite the fact that the process of ousting the M60 with more advanced machine guns, such as the Belgian-designed M240, began in the 1980s, these weapons are still produced and are widely used, albeit primarily in the “second roles”. In terms of design, it was mainly a hybrid of two German-developed systems of the Second World War period - an automatic rifle FG-42 (automatic reloading with a gas engine) and a MG 42 machine gun (tape drive).
M249 SAW
M249 SAW - a variant of the FN Minimi light machine gun for the US Army 5.56? 45 mm caliber manufactured by FN Herstal (Belgium), mass production began in the 1980s. The machine gun entered the service in the armed forces of several countries, among them: Australia, Belgium, Canada, France, Greece, Spain, Italy, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, Thailand, Sweden, the United Kingdom and the United States of America (M249 SAW). Weapons are currently manufactured at FN Herstal factories.

Portable Hand Generator

%c[0,170,170,170]The device is a home-made portable generator with a manual drive. It is based on a single-phase asynchronous motor, from some old electrical appliance. The generated voltage passes through a step-down transformer to a rectifier assembled on Soviet D242 diodes to the Portable Power Unit. Self-excitation of the generator occurs due to the capacitor connected to the auxiliary winding of the motor. The charge is carried out by rotating the rotor through a worm gear at a nominal speed of 1300-1500 rpm. The device is equipped with an American ammeter, manufactured by WESTON ELECTRICAL INSTRUMENT. Due to its design, it has a rather large weight, but is still very much appreciated in the Zone. Some craftsmen can modify this device.

KRISS Vector
KRISS Vector is a submachine gun developed by Transformational Defense Industries. It uses a semi-free shutter system that directs the slide-movable slide group downward at a large angle. This system is called Kriss Super V. The main task of the designers of this weapon was to achieve the highest possible accuracy in bursts using .45 ACP rounds, which have a high stopping effect on the bullet, but at the same time minimize the dimensions and total weight of the submachine gun. Engineers at Transformational Defense Industries, Inc. (TDI) decided to use the patents of the French designer Renaud Kerbrat to achieve their goals. Tests of prototypes of this weapon were launched in 2005. The test results showed that when firing from a TDI KRISS Super V submachine gun, the tossing up of weapons when firing in line is insignificant, which ensures high accuracy of automatic fire and excellent controllability of the weapon during firing. In these parameters, the TDI KRISS Super V submachine gun is significantly superior to such samples as the German 11.43 mm HK UMP45 submachine gun.

M1 Garand

%c[0,170,170,170]M1 Garand - an American self-loading rifle from the Second World War. The M1 Garand rifle became the world's 4th self-loading rifle, adopted for service and the first adopted as the main infantry weapon. Reliable and accurate, it served the US forces in World War II and the war in Korea. General Patton once called this rifle "the greatest warfare ever created." Garand is still popular in the civilian weapons market. The rifle mechanism works on the principle of removal of powder gases through a transverse hole in the barrel wall. The gas piston is fixedly attached to the gate frame. The locking of the shutter by turning occurs when the shutter is rotated around the longitudinal axis and two shutter protrusions enter into the grooves of the receiver. The trigger mechanism is a trigger, a fairly simple device, subsequently often copied in a more or less altered form, when disassembling a weapon, it was completely separated from the receiver. The rifle had a very successful and subsequently often replicated fuse in the form of a lever-flag in the front of the trigger guard, for arming, it moved backward, inside the trigger guard, so that the shooter could easily detect by touch whether the rifle is on guard. If necessary (for example, in the event of a misfire), the trigger could be cocked without “jerking” the shutter by pulling the back of the trigger guard down and forward behind the special ring - another evidence of how much attention the creators of the rifle paid to the convenience of handling weapons.

M16 (the official designation is Rifle, Caliber 5.56 mm, M16) is an American automatic rifle of 5.56 mm caliber, developed on the basis of the AR-15 rifle and adopted in the 1960s. In 1964, the M16 rifle was officially adopted, replacing the M14. In 1966, all American units in Vietnam armed with a new rifle. The rifle proved to be an extremely unreliable type of small arms. In general, it should be recognized that by the beginning of the 1970s, the M16 rifle was a full-fledged combat weapon with a number of significant advantages (well, of course, it also had drawbacks). Compared to the main enemy of the M16 on the world stage - the Kalashnikov assault rifle (AKM), the M16 had greater accuracy and accuracy in firing single shots, was more comfortable and convenient to use. On the other hand, the M16 required much more thorough care, better ammunition. In reliability under especially difficult conditions (pollution, dusting), the AKM also exceeded the M16. M16 and its variants to date remain the main weapon of the American infantry. This is one of the most common models of small arms in the world - more than 8 million copies have been produced.

MP-412 Rex is a Russian-made revolver chambered for .357 Smith end Wesson Magnum (9x33 mm) and .38 Smith end Wesson Special (9.1x29 mm). Designed at the Izhevsk Mechanical Plant in the late 1990s. Designed for export (REX - Revolver for Export), but did not go into mass production. This new IzhMekh revolver is distinguished by two main features - an edging frame in the style of Smith-Wesson of the late XIX - early XX century, and a polymer frame, more precisely - its lower part together with a handle. The upper part of the frame holding the barrel is steel. The revolver has a switchable ejector, in the on state it ejects spent cartridges from the drum when the frame is opened (when the ejector is off, the cartridges only partially extend from the drum).

AA-12

AA-12 (camouflaged)
AA-12 (Auto Assault-12) - automatic shotgun - shotgun, created by Maxwell Atchisson on the basis of earlier development Atchisson Assault Shotgun. The main difference between AA-12 and AAS is the use of gas exhaust automation, which is typical for machine guns, automatic rifles and machine guns, due to the possibility of using more powerful cartridges. Also, the design of the trigger and receiver, completely made with the butt and forend, was changed. Like its predecessor, the shutter rolls back to the butt. The new receiver consists of left and right halves, fastened to each other with pins. The translator of firing modes is located near the trigger and allows firing in single or continuous bursts. A special feature of the gun is the “recoil momentum accumulation”, similar to the Ultimax 100 machine gun. The essence of this solution is the interaction of two return springs, stretching the recoil momentum in time. Later, using the ideas of Atchisson in South Korea, the USAS-12 automatic shotgun was developed.

WA-2000 is a self-loading rifle, the automation of which operates due to the removal of powder gases from the bore. A total of 176 rifles were fired (where it came from in the Zone is another question).

The cult Soviet TT-33 pistol is an improved version of the TT-30 semi-automatic pistol, developed in 1930 to replace the obsolete revolver of the Nagan system arr. 1895 year. Despite the fact that the production of the TT-33 in Russia continued from 1933 to 1954, some copies are still in service and are assembled in Third World countries. The TT pistol is distinguished by its simplicity of design and, therefore, the low cost of production and ease of maintenance. PKP "Pecheneg"
7.62mm machine gun PKP "Pecheneg" (GRAU Index - 6P41) is the Russian single machine gun developed on the basis of PKM. Designed to engage enemy manpower, fire and vehicles, air targets. Designed by TsNIItochmash. The machine gun uses a system of forced air cooling of the barrel due to the energy of powder gases. An adjustable gas vent allows the operation of Pecheneg in any climatic conditions. The barrel has an external ribbing and is enclosed in a metal casing. Powder gases, leaving the trunk, create a rarefaction zone in the front of the casing. In the rear part of the casing, special ventilation windows are made. Thus, during firing along the barrel, cold air is continuously pumped. Constant barrel cooling reduces dispersion during firing and also increases barrel longevity. In general, Pecheneg retained up to 80% percent of the common parts with PCM (receiver with all the mechanisms, the machine), and the increase in fire efficiency was from 150% with fire from the machine to 250% with fire from the bipod (according to the developers).
RPD
7.62mm Degtyarev light machine gun (RPD, GRAU Index - 56-P-327) is a Soviet light machine gun developed in 1944 with a cartridge of 7.62x39 mm. The RPD was one of the first weapons adopted for service under the cartridge of the 1943 model. From the beginning of the 1950s to the mid-1960s, it was the main weapon to support the separation level, and then gradually began to be replaced by the PKK, more preferred in terms of unification. However, the RPD is still in the warehouses of army reserves. Like many other types of Soviet weapons, RPDs were widely exported to countries friendly to the USSR, and also produced abroad, for example, in the PRC under the designation Type 56. Some US firms, such as DC Arms, produce upgraded RPDs. Modernization includes a telescopic butt, forend with Picatinny rails, ergonomic bipod, plastic handle.

Galil ACE-21
The family of assault rifles (assault, automatic rifles) Galil ACE is designed and manufactured by the Israeli weapons company IWI Ltd. The Galil ACE family of assault rifles is based on the design of the Galil assault rifle, which in turn is a development of the AK Kalashnikov assault rifle. The Galil ACE assault rifle line focuses on the ergonomics of the weapon, the convenience of its use and completing with additional accessories, as well as its flexibility of use - the Galil ACE line of weapons includes the three most common types of ammunition in the world (5.56x45 NATO, 7.62x39 M43 and 7.62x51 NATO ), in various options for barrel length. The main differences from its predecessors were the transfer of the shutter cocking handle to the left side of the weapon (now you can conveniently turn the shutter with your left hand without taking your right hand from the fire control handle), a bolt delay appeared in the design of the weapon, the machine received Picatinny rail-type integral rails for installing optics and accessories as well as an adjustable telescopic butt.

In the mid-1980s, the designers of the Izhevsk Machine-Building Plant developed several models of the A-60 and A-61 universal modified Kalashnikov assault rifles. On the basis of the A-60 and A-61, one of the successful versions of the 5.45 mm Kalashnikov AK-74M assault rifle was developed. The design of the AK-74M Kalashnikov assault rifle almost completely repeats the AK-74 scheme and has no fundamental differences from the point of view of the internal structure. Having retained all the best qualities of Kalashnikov assault rifles, he acquired a number of new ones that significantly improved his combat and operational characteristics. In general, the design of the AK-74M embodied the idea of ??a “universal” machine that replaced four models at once - AK-74, AK-74N, AKS-74 and AKS-74N.

CZ 52
CZ vz.52 - self-loading pistol, developed in the early 1950s for the Czechoslovak army. The Cz52 pistol was developed by designer Jan Kratohvil together with his brother Yaroslav, employees of the Ceska zbrojovka Strakonice factory. Initially, the pistol was designed for the 9.19 mm Parabellum cartridge, but in the 1960s a decision was made to unify the ammunition in the Warsaw Treaty countries, as a result of which the pistol was redone for the 7.62x25mm cartridge. Automation works according to the pattern of using recoil with a short barrel stroke. The barrel channel is locked using two rollers and a locking slider located in the lower tide of the rear of the barrel and entering the internal recesses of the shutter-casing. Trigger mechanism - trigger type, single action, with a safety cocking trigger. On the left side of the frame there is a lever for the safety lock, which is also a lever for the safe descent of the trigger from the combat cock. The fuse has three positions. The lower one is “fire”, the upper one is the safe trigger release, and the middle one is the fuse. The built-in shutter latch locks the casing shutter in the extreme rear position after all cartridges are used up from the magazine. At the base of the trigger guard is a double-sided barrel lock. Sights consist of an unregulated front sight and a rear sight fixed in a dovetail groove, with the possibility of lateral amendments. On the bottom surface of the handle there is a magazine latch holding 8 rounds.

The CZ 75 is a pistol developed in Czechoslovakia in 1975. It has become widespread throughout the world. Designed by the brothers Joseph and Frantisek Koucki in Ugorsky Brod. In 1977, mass production was launched. Automation works according to the pattern of using recoil with a short barrel stroke. Locking is carried out using the declining breech. The weapon has high firing accuracy due to the practically backlash-free movement of the shutter-casing, since the design of Charles Peter is used here - moving the shutter-casing not along the external but along the internal guides of the frame. Moreover, the guide grooves are made along the entire length of the frame, which makes the movement stable. It is very popular among various special services, both Czechoslovakia and other countries of the Warsaw Treaty, including the KGB of the USSR. This is due to the significantly higher combat and service and operational qualities of this weapon than the TT and full-time PM.

Glock 18c is an Austrian-made Glock automatic pistol, chambered in 9x19mm Parabellum caliber. Glock 18 aroused the interest of police and military forces, but it did not gained the expected popularity, due to its low automatic fire efficiency, even in comparison with rather compact submachine guns. The Glock 18 inherited all the advantages of the basic Glock 17 pistol and is structurally very similar to it.[1] One of the differences is the fire mode selector lever at the left rear of the slide housing. In popular culture, samples as Glock 18 are often actually converted (with automatic fire capability) Glock 17s, usually with a 33-round magazine. The Glock 18 can easily be distinguished by the muzzle protruding outside the breech-cover, with an integrated reactive compensator that reduces the muzzle flap when firing. The 18C has the same muzzle protrusion and bore as the 17C. Sighting equipment is detachable and installed in cross-hole dovetail style mounts. Standard iron sights are non-adjustable, and include white or glow (tritium) dots for easy aiming in poor lighting conditions.

HK416
HK416 is a German automatic rifle, created by Heckler & Koch on the basis of M4 carbine. Initially, the new weapon was supposed to be a replacement for the M4 or M16 rifle, but later it was replaced by the MK416 rifle. The name HK416 symbolizes the continuity of the M4 and M16 rifles. The receiver is made from aluminum alloy and the magazines are made from steel (standard M16 magazines can also be used). The barrel is hinged in the fore-end of the barrel. The barrel is made from Picatinny or Daniel Defense slats on the upper plane of the receiver, as well as on the four sides of the receiver's forend, so that a wide range of accessories can be used. Multi-position telescopic buttstock is similar in design to the M4. The gun shows high accuracy and pile-up shooting. Due to its high modularity and versatility, the HK416 can be adapted to any type of combat.

HK417
HK417 - 7.62mm automatic rifle, based on HK416 (5.56mm). The rifle features a modular design, similar to that of the M16 rifle, but features gas operated, short-stroke gas piston system, like the HK G36. The barrel is locked by rotary bolt action with 7 locking lugs. The controls and assembly/disassembly procedures are inherited from the M16, but the gas piston system is similar to the HK G36. It can be fired in single shots, or in continuous bursts. The barrel is cold forged and has threads for installing silencer or muzzle brake. The receiver is made from aluminum alloy. The barrel is telescopic and sliding. Polymer clear box magazines were specially designed for HK417, allowing the shooter to control ammunition consumption. Rifle caliber is 7.62x51 NATO. Another feature of the HK417 is the ability to quickly change the barrel by the user, using a minimum number of tools, thus achieving tactical flexibility of the weapon. The HK416/417 rifle has similar capabilities, as well as Belgian FN SCAR rifle. Single shot accuracy is about one corner minute with "sniper" barrel and corresponding cartridges.

Ruger SR-556
Ruger SR-556 is an American self-loading carbine manufactured by Sturm, Ruger & Company, Inc. The weapon was introduced in 2009 and became the first model of the Ruger AR-10 family. The next variant in this range was the Ruger SR-762 carbine with .308 cartridge[2]. This rifle is one of the few AR-15 rifles, which uses powder gas venting. Production ceased in January 2016 after introduction of the Takedown version with lightweight Keymod stock. The rifle is based on the patented AR-15 direct gas blowback mechanism, which operates in two stages and is opposed to the AR-15 direct gas blowback system. Powder gas venting is controlled by four-stage regulator. Several key parts - short stroke gas piston, gas regulator and bolt group - are chrome plated. Instead of the AR-15 gas piston, there is a built-in tab in the bolt. Flame arrester is similar to the AC-556 and Mini-14GB flame arresters.

PMM
The 9mm Makarov pistol is a modernized PMM (GRAU Index - 56-A-125M) - a Russian pistol developed in the early 1990s as part of the research and development theme "Grac". The pistol has a reinforced frame and increased bolt weight. The PMM pistol is equipped with spiral grooves, which allows to use 9x18mm PMM high pulsed cartridges for firing. When the gun is fired, the pressure of the powder gases presses the shell walls into three grooves on the chamber walls, holding the shell in the chamber until the bullet leaves the barrel and the pressure decreases, after which the shell is extracted and ejected. The maximum pressure in the channel of the gun barrel increased by 15% with a new cartridge, which slightly increased the recoil. 70 % of PMM pistol parts are interchangeable with PM pistol.

PL-15
Lebedev's pistol (PL-15) - developed by Russian self-loading pistol under the cartridge 9?19 mm Parabellum. The PL-15 is a short-stroke, recoil operated weapon that uses short-stroke inertia of the bolt, linked to the barrel. The bolt is unlocked by lowering the barrel by the curved tide below the barrel. The barrel channel is locked by hitch on the upper edge of the barrel when it is coupled to the ejection port in the bolt. Double action, curved, with concealed trigger and inertial striker. Self-propelled shots are fired in self-loading mode for each shot, with 4 kg of trigger force and 7 mm full stroke. In addition, a manual safety feature is provided, and the trigger is detachable from the trigger with trigger and has two flat levers on both sides of the weapon. Cartridge indicator in the chamber is made in the form of a pin, which protrudes from the rear end of the bolt, when cartridge is in the barrel. The bolt levers are reversible. The PL-15 pistol is fitted with extended threaded barrel for quick-release silencer.

The USAS-12 is an automatic shotgun developed by John Trevor in the late 1980s based on the ideas of another American designer, Maxwell Atchisson, who created the Atchisson Assault Shotgun. USAS-12 uses automation based on the removal of powder gases from the bore with locking the barrel by turning the shutter. As well as in AAS / AA-12, the plastic butt is made hollow so that the bolt group would roll back into it when shooting. This solution reduces the rate of fire and reduces recoil. To ensure "two-sidedness", the windows of the sleeve extractor, as well as cutouts for the cocking handle of the shutter, are available on both sides of the receiver. The three-position fuse-translator of the firing modes is similar to that of the M16 assault rifle. The receiver has an integrated carrying handle.

The Remington 870 is an American shotgun, first introduced in 1950 by Remington Arms. Due to its characteristic reloading it is one of the most famous pump-action shotguns in the world. Available in various versions, it is suitable for military and police use, as well as for hunters and athletes, and in self-defense. It is with this gun that Fox went on his last chimera hunt, which proves that even an experienced hunter with a good weapon may not come back after meeting with chimera. The shotgun has high damage due to its chrome plating on the inside of the barrel.

SPAS-12 (rusty)
Smooth automatic special purpose shotgun with switchable firing modes, with open buttstock. Developed back in the second half of XX century, it continues to be used as a universal combat weapon by police and assault units of the army. It is distinguished by high reliability and tactical flexibility. Despite its large mass, sophisticated device and high price, it is quite popular in the Zone as an effective means to combat mutants. Mechanisms on this model are slightly upgraded, parts are tightly fitted to each other, thanks to this it was possible to significantly increase the killing of weapons, but do not forget about the weakened side of the weapon, the gaps in the channels decreased, and therefore the resource of the barrel.

AC «Val»
The special "Val" rifle is based on the silent VSS "Vintorez" sniper rifle. It was developed for arming special purpose units of the Soviet Army and the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The main purpose of the rifle is to effectively defeat the enemy, using modern personal protective equipment, without revealing the position of the shooter. Thanks to the integrated silencer and 9x39 cartridge with heavy sonic bullet, the sound of the shot and muzzle flame are minimized.

SR-3M "Vikhr" is a compact Russian automatic rifle developed in Klimovsk TsNIITOCHMASH by designers A.D. Borisov and V.N. Levchenko in 1994. It was manufactured by designer A. I. Tashlykov and was launched into mass production in 1996. It is based on the silent automatic rifle AS "Val", with which it is unified in basic details, which has a positive impact on the production and operation of weapons. The SR-3 is similar to the AS "Val" in general: gas operated weapon and bolt locking with 6 locking lugs. The SR-3M was developed later, and features a silencer, metal magazines for 30 rounds, telescope and night sights, folding left frame buttstock (borrowed from AS "Val"), flag fuse, made on the type of SVD, and a new forend.

Small-size automatic carbine 9A-91 was developed in 1992 as a more technological analogue and competitor of SR-3 "Vortex" in Tula Instrument Design Bureau. Automatic carbine 9A-91 is based on discharge of powder gases from the barrel channel. It is locked by rotating the bolt with 4 locking lugs. The bolt is of the trigger type, and can be fired in single and continuous bursts. The bolt carrier is located at the left side of the receiver, above the trigger guard (in the upgraded version - at the right side of the receiver, as the telescope sights are mounted on the left side of the receiver). Early versions had muzzle brake-compensator, but later it was discarded. The buttstock was folded upward and forward. The receiver was made from steel, as well as all other parts, except plastic pistol grip and chains. When folded, the automatic rifle is suitable for covert carrying. The bolt handle is also made from folded steel for easy concealed carrying. Unlike the Kalashnikov assault rifle, the slit for the bolt handle is always open.

Gauss rifle “Product 62”
The super-precision high-tech weapon, known as "Product No. 62", was developed by designers of secret laboratories within the Zone. Its principle of operation is based on the overclocking of the bullet by a system of electromagnets; the bullet is capable of developing super speed, which provides a colossal punching ability with almost no recoil. Particles of some artifacts are used to ensure sufficient power capacity of batteries.

The gun is very popular and has been adopted by several countries in the world.

Soviet combat knife-bayonet
This Soviet steel knife has a 132-mm blade with a large choyal toe, a brown wooden handle and an S-shaped guard. It is a reverse type of garment, as the standard Soviet knife grip is a blade to itself. The handle is reinforced with a coarse overlay for better retention. The knife is relatively small, which does not allow deep wounds to be inflicted, but it is capable of piercing bulletproof vests.
 
%c[ui_red] - %c[ui_red] Not intended for cutting huge objects.
 

Hunting knife
A big hunting knife with a reliable rubberized grip. Sharp and in good condition. Not suitable for piercing bulletproof vests, but thanks to a serrated blade it cuts flesh well, keeping the wound from closing. This makes it an ideal weapon against animals, especially when piercing.
Soviet combat knife
The Soviet combat knife used during the Second World War. It has a small popularity among stalkers in the Zone.

Special Forces folding knife
Folding knife of extremely high quality, ideal for scouts. It is an extremely lethal weapon and the only knife in the Zone that penetrates the vests equally well and inflicts serious wounds to the unprotected flesh. It's an excellent close combat weapon.
Long hunting knife
Very robust hunting knife with large stainless steel blade. Ideal for hunting mutants, cutting meat and thick skins. The knife is able to cause extensive bleeding wounds. Its disadvantage is that it cannot penetrate heavy armor.

Steyr AUG A1 in standard configuration with fixed 1.5x optical sights. AUG (Armee Universal Gewehr - army universal rifle) is an Austrian 5.56mm bullpup assault rifle, developed by Steyr Mannlicher GmbH & Co KG during 1960s. In 1978 AUG was adopted by Austrian army as standard small arms under the designation of StG 77, where it replaced the 7.62mm StG 58 automatic rifle (licensed FN FAL). The rifle and its variants have also been adopted by the armies of Argentina, Australia, Malaysia, New Zealand, Bolivia, Ecuador, Ireland, Luxembourg, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia, Pakistan, as well as by the US border guard.

Steyr AUG A3
AUG (Armee Universal Gewehr) - small arms complex, produced in 1977 by Austrian company Steyr-Daimler-Puch. The Steyr AUG A3 differs from the basic model by its four Picatinny bars: the upper barrel is used to attach the sights, the lower barrel can be fitted with underbarrel grenade launcher or vertical front grip, and the lateral barrel can be fitted with a laser designator or other necessary additional equipment.
